title: Create compliance reports for Red Hat products
content:
To create compliance reports for Red Hat products, follow these steps:

  1. Run required discovery jobs to prepare UD/UCMDB data.
    Make sure you run the Inventory Discovery by Scanner  job before synchronizing the product family from UD/UCMDB, otherwise the names of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) products may not correspond with the out-of-the-box (OOTB) ones. However, the following features provided by SAM are only applicable to the OOTB RHEL products:
    • View the Potential license cost optimization for Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) report on SAM Home. 
    • Optimize the license costs based on the calculated license cost optimization threshold. For more information about the threshold, see the Configure license rules and properties section of this topic.
    After running the discovery job, if the product names still don't match with the OOTB ones, you need to normalize the imported products to guarantee the accuracy of compliance reports generated by SAM. For instructions on how to normalize products, see Configurations.
  2. Synchronize the product family.
    After syncing the product family, go to the Products page and select Enterprise Linux. On the General tab, you can check whether the discovered product versions of RHEL have been mapped to the OOTB RHEL products in the Imported product list. Note that the product code is RED HAT_ENTERPRISE LINUX.
  3. Maintain license compatibility matrix based on the publisher's official documentation. 
  4. Configure license rules and properties.
    • Configure license rules
      The following license rules are available for Red Hat products. For more information about these rules, see Supported software titles.
      • Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server
      • Red Hat Enterprise Linux for Virtual Datacenters
    • Configure properties
      During license consumption calculation, SAM considers the license cost optimization threshold for RHEL Server and RHEL for Virtual Datacenters. The threshold is calculated by dividing the subscription price of RHEL for Virtual Datacenter by the price of RHEL Server. If you get a different price than the standard price, you can use this algorithm to calculate the threshold and update the default value (7.2). In addition, you can calculate a ratio by dividing the total number of consumed RHEL Server licenses by the number of consumed RHEL for VDC licenses, and compare it with the cost optimization threshold value to determine whether a virtual environment is high-density or low-density.
      The following table illustrates the correspondences between the comparison results and virtual environment types:
      Comparison result Virtual environment

      The calculated ratio ≥ the threshold

      High-density

      The calculated ratio < the threshold

      Low-density
      The cost-efficiency of RHEL Server and RHEL for VDC licenses differs in different production environments:
      • The RHEL Server license is more cost-efficient in a low-density virtual environment, and it can be used in both physical and virtual environments.
      • The RHEL for VDC license is more cost-efficient in a high-density environment because it supports an unlimited number of virtual machines.
  5. Configure license models to build license pool information.
    For more information about the settings, see Software coverage. 
    • For the RHEL Server license, choose the Per Socket-pair (Server) license metric.
    • For the RHEL for VDC license, choose the Per Socket-pair (VDC) license metric. 
  6. Calculate license consumption.
    During license consumption process, SAM follows certain priority order by default in different environments:
    Environment Priority order for license consumption 
    Virtual

    High-density 

    RHEL for VDC

    Low-density

    RHEL for VDC > RHEL Server

    To make full use of the existing licenses, the surplus RHEL for VDC licenses will be consumed prior to the RHEL Server licenses even though the RHEL Server license is a more economical choice in this environment.
    Physical RHEL Server
    The table below provides license purchasing suggestions for unlicensed environments:
    Environment  License purchasing suggestion
    Virtual

    High-density 

    RHEL for VDC

    Low-density

    RHEL Server
    Physical RHEL Server
  7. View compliance status.
    In the product compliance report, you would see both the Per Socket-pair (Server) and Per Socket-pair (VDC) in the Product version section, when the following conditions are met:
    • You have both RHEL Server and RHEL for VDC licenses.
    • You are suggested to purchase new licenses for unlicensed devices according to the threshold value.
  8. Analyze compliance report.
    When you review the consumption details for Red Hat Enterprise Linux products in Analysis, you will see two result sets for a virtual environment, and the highlighted check mark ( ) indicates the consumption result aggregated for product compliance calculation. For a physical environment, you'll only see one result of RHEL Server.
